Misfortune and the University.

It must have touched the heart
of every Hopkins man to hear
President Goodnow, on Commemoration Day, review the many misfortunes that had befallen the University within the past year. It
is true enough that there were
some to which we might reconcile
ourselves, but there were others
which are irreparable. The sacrifices that the University has been
called upon or has offered to make
to the god of war are, at least,
temporary and will in some future
day, we believe, bear results commensurate with the present loss.
But there have been other misfortunes that have left us with a
sense of total loss, with no possible hope of recovery. Within the
last six months, the faculty of the
University has been reduced no
less than four ,times—the last
time, only last Wednesday—by the
inexorable stroke of death.
The death of Prof. Edward H.
Spieker during the past week
marks the most recent loss the
University has suffered within so
short a period of time. It marks
the loss of a man the productive
years of whose life were coextensive with the period of the birth and
development of this University. It
is not for us, who know at best
only particular phases of the life
of Professor Spieker, to attempt
to appraise his services to the University and to his particular field

A Memorable Day and a New Tradition.

The forty-second anniversary
will live long in the history of
the University and in the memories of those who could be present. It was the first Commemoration Day of the great war. If
the exercises on this day were always solemn and serious, they
were this year more solemn and
more serious than ever before;
they were more than that—they
were grim, they were martial.
McCoy Hall, rich in Hopkins history and traditions, was the scene
of the ceremonies. A guard of
honor, formed by the khaki-clad
members of the Hopkins Battalion, lined both sides of the broad
corridor through which passed
the academic procession, with
ranks thinned noticeably, and
marked by the service uniform
as well as cap and gown. Hundreds of alumni, whose custom it
had ever been on this day to pay
their respects to their Alma Mater
and to refresh cherished memories
of student days, were missing.
The influence of war pervaded the
address of the orator, the report
of the President, and even the invocation. Nevertheless, the feelings that were aroused were those
not of despair, but of unyielding
determination.
Not the least significant feature
of the exercises was the presence
of the undergraduate students in
force. Whether it was military
necessity or the impulse of college
loyalty that prompted the establishment of this tradition matters not. A tradition has been
established, which no man could
help but feel was worthy of preservation for all future years. The
honor and glory that has come
and that will continue to come to
the founders and President and
graduates of the University is
shared with and reflected upon
all the members of the University.
This is a timely opportunity for
undergraduates to pay the tribute
they owe to the founders of the
University, to the President of

the present Committee is the division of
the University, for the purpose of residence
only, not of instruction, into a number of
small communities, similar to the colleges
of an English university, rather than to
the dormitories of an American college,
and each one comprising so far as possible
all the elements found in the University
body—undergraduates of all classes, graduate students, fellows and unmarried instructors, rich and poor, fraternity and nonfraternity, "sports' and "grinds."
Each
community should be so far as possible both
governed and managed by a committee of
its own members, but it must not be permitted to control its membership. Incoming students should be assigned by the
University in such manner as to preserve
the representative character of every community. Each of these should be large
enough to avoid the appearance of forcing
intimacy between uncongenial members, but
small enough to foster such intercourse
among men of different antecedants and
tastes as will lead at least to mutual knowledge and esteem, and also to secure the influence of the more mature in forming the
tastes and characters of the younger. This
is one of the chief objects of the system.
It should also be housed so as to further
this end and to arouse affection and loyalty
in later life. The Committee considers from
100 to 125 persons to be the number best
suited to fulfill the former condition, and to
meet the latter it deems it essential that

building should enclose three sides of a
quadrangle, from which all entries open,
with a fence or hedge on the fourth side,

an outdoor center for the members. While
the Committee recommends as much variety
as possible in detail of buildings, differences
in the scale of comfort or in cost of living, such as would lead to distinctions between the various communities arising from

should under no circumstances be tolerated.

Experiment work at Johns Hopkins University by Dr. David 1.
Macht, instructor of medicine and
lecturer on pharnuxcology, has developed a partial substitute for
opium. The new drug has been
named "benzyle benzolate" and in
certain instances works with success.
Announcement of the discovery
of the drug was made Wednesday
night by Dr. Macht before the Society for Experimental Biology
and Medicine at the College of the
City of New York. The substitute
has met with the approval of Dr.
Thomas R. Brown, head of the intestinal clinic at Johns Hopkins
University.
In discussing the discovery last
night, Dr. Macht said the communication he made in New York
was of a technical nature, intended for scientists only. "I cannot
make any further statement," he
said, "because it would be premature and inadvisable."
The new drug, which Dr. Macht
has tried on animals and even subjected himself to a test, is a coal
tar derivative and lacks toxic after effects. It has been used in the
manufacture of perfumes. Though
much research work has been done
in connection with perfecting the
drug the developments are not yet
complete and there is a good deal
still to be accomplished.

Patient Photographer Struggles With
Capricious Temperaments of Hopkins Operatic and Orchestral Artists.

There Is a rumor abroad that
the combined musical clubs posed
with great glee for a picture last
week. In accordance with an ancient custom, these song-birds and
jazzers arrayed themselves in Sunday garments known among the
waiters' union as "bib-and-tuckers." One young Edison was so
hard up for shirt studs that he
used brass paper fasteners, and
several more were unable to extract from Uncle Benny the proper
black trousers. This bothered them
not at all, however, for the photographer invoked the gods to bear
witness that if the trousers show
ed up light in the picture, he
would darken them himsdlf.
The studio, on a second floor,
"somewhere on Charles street,"
• had the advantage of a tine outlook. In fact, the entire front wall
was a sheet of plate glass. The
group, posed near this, was afforded a splendid opportunity to view
the street below with its sights so
rare; likewise, it was not long before a mob of girls had gathered in
this street to gaze admiringly
upon the brave display of manly
beauty above. The photographer
was also lost in admiration of the
melody-murderers, and remarked
that it "vas a classy bunch."
Many obstacles had to be overcome before the picture could be
taken, however. The treasurer was
in great fear that his tan shoes
would show. The director of singing arriving late had to make a
quick change. Several four-eyed
birds were unable to clroose quickly between taking their glasses off
and leaving them on, on account
of the sights in Charles street
which they were afraid of missing.
At last, nevertheless, after tearful
urgings, everybody assumed a
graceful pose and concentrated
what was left of his mind upon
being handsome and serious. Four
shots were taken, in the hope that
one might turn out fit to be printed in the "Hullabaloo."

made an awful fool of myself.
Miss Kutting—That's nothing
to brag about. You had ideal material to work with.—Judge.

Dr. William S. Baer, who went
to France last June as a member
of the Johns Hopkins Base Hospital [nit, with the rank of major
hi the Medical Reserve Corps, is
socin to be made a lieutenantcolonel, according to an announcement made yesterday at the headquarters of the Army Medical
Corps in Washington. It was
stated that Dr. Baer's new commission had not been forwarded
to him, but that it would soon be
issued and his promotion made
effective. This action will be a recognition of the valuable services
which he is performing in the
field.
Since January 10 Major Baer
has been acting as assistant director of orthopedic surgery
to the American Expeditionary
Force, with general supervision
over operative work in the base
and evacuation hospitals. • In consequence of being assigned to this
work he has ben transferred from
the Medical Reserve to the Army
Medical Corps and is therefore
eligible for a higher rank than
that of major, which is the highest
in the Medical Reserve Corps.
Dr. John M. T. Finney, head of
the Johns Hopkins Base Hospital
Unit, was promoted in this manner some time ago, and now holds
the position of medical director,
with the rank of lieutenantcolonel. It is rumored that other
sweeping changes will soon be announced affecting members of the
unit, including Dr. William A.
Fisher, Jr., who will probably be
made a lieutenant-colonel, and Dr.
Finney, who may receive a
colonel's commission. Dr. Fisher
has already been detached from
the Hopkins unit for general surgical work with the American
forces.
Dr. Baer, who is associate professor of surgery at the Medical
School and head of the Department of Orthopedic Surgery at
Johns Hopkins Hospital, is one of
the most famous orthopedic surgeons in this country.
Before the Johns Hopkins Base
Hospital was established in permanent quarters lie was at the
French front with a surgical unit
for a number of weeks, where he
had many thrilling experiences,
operating practically under fire
during the Ovtober offensive on
the Aisne front. The surgeons at
the hospital where he was working Were divided into teams, each
working continuously for eight
hours, resting and doing dressings
for the next eight hours and then
back to work again. During the
worst of the attack 5,000 cases
were operated on in three days.

Misfortune and the University.

It must have touched the heart
of every Hopkins man to hear
President Goodnow, on Commemoration Day, review the many misfortunes that had befallen the University within the past year. It
is true enough that there were
some to which we might reconcile
ourselves, but there were others
which are irreparable. The sacrifices that the University has been
called upon or has offered to make
to the god of war are, at least,
temporary and will in some future
day, we believe, bear results commensurate with the present loss.
But there have been other misfortunes that have left us with a
sense of total loss, with no possible hope of recovery. Within the
last six months, the faculty of the
University has been reduced no
less than four ,times—the last
time, only last Wednesday—by the
inexorable stroke of death.
The death of Prof. Edward H.
Spieker during the past week
marks the most recent loss the
University has suffered within so
short a period of time. It marks
the loss of a man the productive
years of whose life were coextensive with the period of the birth and
development of this University. It
is not for us, who know at best
only particular phases of the life
of Professor Spieker, to attempt
to appraise his services to the University and to his particular field

A Memorable Day and a New Tradition.

The forty-second anniversary
will live long in the history of
the University and in the memories of those who could be present. It was the first Commemoration Day of the great war. If
the exercises on this day were always solemn and serious, they
were this year more solemn and
more serious than ever before;
they were more than that—they
were grim, they were martial.
McCoy Hall, rich in Hopkins history and traditions, was the scene
of the ceremonies. A guard of
honor, formed by the khaki-clad
members of the Hopkins Battalion, lined both sides of the broad
corridor through which passed
the academic procession, with
ranks thinned noticeably, and
marked by the service uniform
as well as cap and gown. Hundreds of alumni, whose custom it
had ever been on this day to pay
their respects to their Alma Mater
and to refresh cherished memories
of student days, were missing.
The influence of war pervaded the
address of the orator, the report
of the President, and even the invocation. Nevertheless, the feelings that were aroused were those
not of despair, but of unyielding
determination.
Not the least significant feature
of the exercises was the presence
of the undergraduate students in
force. Whether it was military
necessity or the impulse of college
loyalty that prompted the establishment of this tradition matters not. A tradition has been
established, which no man could
help but feel was worthy of preservation for all future years. The
honor and glory that has come
and that will continue to come to
the founders and President and
graduates of the University is
shared with and reflected upon
all the members of the University.
This is a timely opportunity for
undergraduates to pay the tribute
they owe to the founders of the
University, to the President of
the University, and to the graduates of the University; to reconsecrate themselves to the high
ideals and purposes embodied in
the name of the Johns Hopkins
University.

Fundamental Plan. The fundamental principle of the system proposed by the Committee of 1910 and again recommended by
the present Committee is the division of
the University, for the purpose of residence
only, not of instruction, into a number of
small communities, similar to the colleges
of an English university, rather than to
the dormitories of an American college,
and each one comprising so far as possible
all the elements found in the University
body—undergraduates of all classes, graduate students, fellows and unmarried instructors, rich and poor, fraternity and nonfraternity, "sports' and "grinds."
Each
community should be so far as possible both
governed and managed by a committee of
its own members, but it must not be permitted to control its membership. Incoming students should be assigned by the
University in such manner as to preserve
the representative character of every community. Each of these should be large
enough to avoid the appearance of forcing
intimacy between uncongenial members, but
small enough to foster such intercourse
among men of different antecedants and
tastes as will lead at least to mutual knowledge and esteem, and also to secure the influence of the more mature in forming the
tastes and characters of the younger. This
is one of the chief objects of the system.
It should also be housed so as to further
this end and to arouse affection and loyalty
in later life. The Committee considers from
100 to 125 persons to be the number best
suited to fulfill the former condition, and to
meet the latter it deems it essential that
each community shall have its own dininghall and commons, 14oth rooms to be of a
dignified and attractive character. Each
building should enclose three sides of a
quadrangle, from which all entries open,
with a fence or hedge on the fourth side,
to give the idea of privacy and to furnish
an outdoor center for the members. While
the Committee recommends as much variety
as possible in detail of buildings, differences
in the scale of comfort or in cost of living, such as would lead to distinctions between the various communities arising from
the pecuniary means of the occupants,
should under no circumstances be tolerated.

strict attention to economy essential in
planning and constructing the residences,

School Makes Important Discovery — New Drug is Coal
Tar Derivative.

Experiment work at Johns Hopkins University by Dr. David 1.
Macht, instructor of medicine and
lecturer on pharnuxcology, has developed a partial substitute for
opium. The new drug has been
named "benzyle benzolate" and in
certain instances works with success.
Announcement of the discovery
of the drug was made Wednesday
night by Dr. Macht before the Society for Experimental Biology
and Medicine at the College of the
City of New York. The substitute
has met with the approval of Dr.
Thomas R. Brown, head of the intestinal clinic at Johns Hopkins
University.
In discussing the discovery last
night, Dr. Macht said the communication he made in New York
was of a technical nature, intended for scientists only. "I cannot
make any further statement," he
said, "because it would be premature and inadvisable."
The new drug, which Dr. Macht
has tried on animals and even subjected himself to a test, is a coal
tar derivative and lacks toxic after effects. It has been used in the
manufacture of perfumes. Though
much research work has been done
in connection with perfecting the
drug the developments are not yet
complete and there is a good deal
still to be accomplished.

There Is a rumor abroad that
the combined musical clubs posed
with great glee for a picture last
week. In accordance with an ancient custom, these song-birds and
jazzers arrayed themselves in Sunday garments known among the
waiters' union as "bib-and-tuckers." One young Edison was so
hard up for shirt studs that he
used brass paper fasteners, and
several more were unable to extract from Uncle Benny the proper
black trousers. This bothered them
not at all, however, for the photographer invoked the gods to bear
witness that if the trousers show
ed up light in the picture, he
would darken them himsdlf.
The studio, on a second floor,
"somewhere on Charles street,"
• had the advantage of a tine outlook. In fact, the entire front wall
was a sheet of plate glass. The
group, posed near this, was afforded a splendid opportunity to view
the street below with its sights so
rare; likewise, it was not long before a mob of girls had gathered in
this street to gaze admiringly
upon the brave display of manly
beauty above. The photographer
was also lost in admiration of the
melody-murderers, and remarked
that it "vas a classy bunch."
Many obstacles had to be overcome before the picture could be
taken, however. The treasurer was
in great fear that his tan shoes
would show. The director of singing arriving late had to make a
quick change. Several four-eyed
birds were unable to clroose quickly between taking their glasses off
and leaving them on, on account
of the sights in Charles street
which they were afraid of missing.
At last, nevertheless, after tearful
urgings, everybody assumed a
graceful pose and concentrated
what was left of his mind upon
being handsome and serious. Four
shots were taken, in the hope that
one might turn out fit to be printed in the "Hullabaloo."

Dr. William S. Baer, who went
to France last June as a member
of the Johns Hopkins Base Hospital [nit, with the rank of major

Since January 10 Major Baer

Force, with general supervision
over operative work in the base
and evacuation hospitals. • In consequence of being assigned to this

the Medical Reserve to the Army
Medical Corps and is therefore
eligible for a higher rank than
that of major, which is the highest
in the Medical Reserve Corps.
Dr. John M. T. Finney, head of
the Johns Hopkins Base Hospital
Unit, was promoted in this manner some time ago, and now holds
the position of medical director,
with the rank of lieutenantcolonel. It is rumored that other
sweeping changes will soon be announced affecting members of the
unit, including Dr. William A.
Fisher, Jr., who will probably be
made a lieutenant-colonel, and Dr.
Finney, who may receive a
colonel's commission. Dr. Fisher
has already been detached from
the Hopkins unit for general surgical work with the American
forces.
Dr. Baer, who is associate professor of surgery at the Medical
School and head of the Department of Orthopedic Surgery at
Johns Hopkins Hospital, is one of
the most famous orthopedic surgeons in this country.
Before the Johns Hopkins Base
Hospital was established in permanent quarters lie was at the
French front with a surgical unit
for a number of weeks, where he
had many thrilling experiences,
operating practically under fire
during the Ovtober offensive on
the Aisne front. The surgeons at
the hospital where he was working Were divided into teams, each
working continuously for eight
hours, resting and doing dressings
for the next eight hours and then
back to work again. During the
worst of the attack 5,000 cases
were operated on in three days.
